> Remember the code I used to create a plot of the density function of a *standard normal* distribution:


```{r}
# Generate a vector of x-values
x = seq(-3, 3, length.out = 1000)
y = dnorm(x)

plot(x, y, main = "Standard Normal PDF", type = "l")
abline(h = 0)
```


Instructions

1. Use the code above as a template to plot a density curve for a normal distribution with:
- mean = 10.4
- standard deviation = 2.4
2. Include an informative title that states the mean and standard deviation values you used.
3. Save your figure to a file called `norm_1.png`.


<div class="hintborder">
- Hint: check out the help entry for `dnorm()` for a description of the arguments.
</div>

<div class="questionborder">
### Questions

- Q1 (1 pt).  What are the parameters and their values for the *standard Normal* distribution?
- Q2 (2 pts).  Paste the R code you used to create and save your figure into the text-entry window.
- Q1 (1 pts).  Paste the image file of your figure into the file entry box. 
</div>


Solution
========

- The standard normal has mean = 0 and sd = 1.

```{r echo=TRUE, results='wait'}

# Mean and sd for normal density curve:
mean_1 = 10.4
sd_1 = 2.4

# Generate a vector of x-values
x_lim = c(mean_1 - 3 * sd_1, mean_1 + 3 * sd_1)

x = seq(x_lim[1], x_lim[2], length.out = 1000)
y = dnorm(x, mean = mean_1, sd = sd_1)

if (FALSE)
  png(
    file.path(
      find_file(
        filename = "lab_04_uncertainty_and_error", 
        directory = TRUE),
      "norm_1.png"), 
    width = 1200, height = 1400, res = 220)

plot(
  x, y, 
  main = paste0("Normal PDF: mean = ", mean_1, " sd = ", sd_1),
  type = "l")
abline(h = 0)

if (FALSE)
  dev.off()

```

```{r, echo=FALSE, eval=FALSE}

mean_1 = 10.4
sd_1 = 2.4

norm_17 = rnorm(n = 17, mean = mean_1, sd = sd_1)
norm_30 = rnorm(n = 30, mean = mean_1, sd = sd_1)
norm_300 = rnorm(n = 300, mean = mean_1, sd = sd_1)
```
